briefdescription.para: Protected constructor prevents instantiation by non-derived classes.
may only be called during constructor
may only be called during constructor
Allow the flowgraph to set for sorting and partitioning.
Tests if there is a handler attached to port which_port.

detaileddescription.para: The sybolic name of the block, which is used in the block_registry. The name is assigned by the block's constructor and never changes during the life of the block.
True if the block has an alias (see set_block_alias).
Returns the block's alias as a string.
Returns the block's alias as PMT.
Set's a new alias for the block; also adds an entry into the block_registry to get the block using either the alias or the original symbol name.
Returns the available input message ports for a block. The return object is a PMT vector that is filled with PMT symbols.
Returns the available output message ports for a block. The return object is a PMT vector that is filled with PMT symbols.
Accept msg, place in queue, arrange for thread to be awakened if it's not already.

briefdescription.para: are all msg ports with handlers empty?
How many messages in the queue?

simplesect.para: returns pmt at head of queue or pmt::pmt_t() if empty.

parameterdescription.para: The message port from which to get the message.

simplesect.para: returns pmt at head of queue or pmt::pmt_t() if empty.

briefdescription.para: Set up the RPC registered variables.

detaileddescription.para: This must be overloaded by a block that wants to use controlport. This is where rpcbasic_register_{get,set} pointers are created, which then get wrapped as shared pointers (rpcbasic_sptr(...)) and stored using add_rpc_variable.

briefdescription.para: Ask if this block has been registered to the RPC.

detaileddescription.para: We can only register a block once, so we use this to protect us from calling it multiple times.

briefdescription.para: When the block is registered with the RPC, set this.
Confirm that ninputs and noutputs is an acceptable combination.

detaileddescription.para:
ninputs
number of input streams connected
noutputs
number of output streams connected
true if this is a valid configuration for this block. This function is called by the runtime system whenever the topology changes. Most classes do not need to override this. This check is in addition to the constraints specified by the input and output gr::io_signatures.

briefdescription.para: Set the callback that is fired when messages are available.

detaileddescription.para: msg_handler can be any kind of function pointer or function object that has the signature: void msg_handler(pmt::pmt msg);
(You may want to use boost::bind to massage your callable into the correct form. See gr::blocks::nop for an example that sets up a class method as the callback.)
Blocks that desire to handle messages must call this method in their constructors to register the handler that will be invoked when messages are available.

If the block inherits from block, the runtime system will ensure that msg_handler is called in a thread-safe manner, such that work and msg_handler will never be called concurrently. This allows msg_handler to update state variables without having to worry about thread-safety issues with work, general_work or another invocation of msg_handler.
If the block inherits from hier_block2, the runtime system will ensure that no reentrant calls are made to msg_handler.

briefdescription.para: The abstract base class for all signal processing blocks.

Basic blocks are the bare abstraction of an entity that has a name, a set of inputs and outputs, and a message queue. These are never instantiated directly; rather, this is the abstract parent class of both gr_hier_block, which is a recursive container, and block, which implements actual signal processing functions.
